claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination is proposed to trigger type I interferon signaling and increase antigen processing/presentation in the tumor.

evidence.quote: 1. Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.
2. Interferon-associated antigen processing and presentation pathways increase.

claims.caveat: This is presented as a proposed mechanistic chain, and the report notes that some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination broadened tumor antigen display in immunopeptidomics (62.3% versus 37.3% of tumor proteins represented).

evidence.quote: | Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination |
3. A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.

claims.caveat: The report cautions that mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors, so the magnitude of peptide-display changes may differ across settings.

claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination expanded the fraction of proteins represented in the MHC-I peptidome (40.6% versus 20.6%).

evidence.quote: | Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape |
3. A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.

claims.caveat: These measurements are drawn from preclinical tumor-model experiments, and the report notes that effects observed in mice may not translate directly across all human tumors.

claims.claim: mRNA vaccination increased PD-L1 expression in tumor tissue (2.4x), supporting a rationale for combining vaccination with checkpoint blockade.

evidence.quote: | PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x | Checkpoint axis became more targetable |
4. PD-L1 pathway activity also increases, creating a rationale for combining with checkpoint blockade.

claims.caveat: An increase in PD-L1 does not by itself prove improved clinical benefit, and the report emphasizes that prospective randomized studies are required before clinical protocol changes are justified.

claims.claim: In a retrospective metastatic patient cohort receiving ICI therapy, prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination was associated with improved survival (p=0.01).

evidence.quote: - Translational arm: a retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.
| Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment |
- The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.

claims.caveat: Because the analysis is retrospective with varied vaccination timing and heterogeneous tumor types/treatment histories, the observed association cannot be interpreted as causal.

claims.claim: Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the sensitization benefit attributed to intratumoral mRNA vaccination.

evidence.quote: - Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.
1. Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.

claims.caveat: This perturbation result is reported for the preclinical system, and the report notes that mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
